snippet.textDisplay: I used to live in Warlingham and can tell you for a fact that that 'Upper' Warlingham is nowhere near the town proper, which is ironically much higher up a hill than the station. It should be called Upper Whyteleafe!

snippet.textDisplay:
Long time fan and subscriber, never had cause to question your vast knowledge before. (I honestly mean that, it wasn't meant sarcastically!)

48 people? I've seen more folk do that OSI in a week, Is this based purely on Oyster Card data? There's gotta be a fault in the data capture somewhere.

It could well be the least used in ahem London, but could it be some form of anomaly as Upper Warlingham is the last station on the Grinstead/Uckfield line inside the 1-6 zones, whereas Whyteleaf continues Oyster/zonal service all the way to Caterham?
Paper tickets, available with that OSI/route will probably make up the majority of folk travelling from EGR/Uck lines, therefore not appearing in figures?

Dunno, apologies for rambling, hope it makes sense.

I do love the vids, not trying to be the one comment who starts a disagreement.
snippet.textOriginal:

It could well be the least used in *ahem* London, but could it be some form of anomaly as Upper Warlingham is the last station on the Grinstead/Uckfield line inside the 1-6 zones, whereas Whyteleaf continues Oyster/zonal service all the way to Caterham? 
Paper tickets, available with that OSI/route will probably make up the majority of folk travelling from EGR/Uck lines, therefore not appearing in figures?

Dunno, apologies for rambling, hope it makes sense.

I do love the vids, not trying to be the one comment who starts a disagreement.

snippet.textDisplay: Brought back loads of memories Geoff, lived in Warlingham for over 20 years, used the train for many years into London, my parents had a Pet Store in Whyteleafe and my Father had a Private Hire Company at Whyteleafe Station, all long gone now, but Happy Days I'm talking like 30 plus years.

snippet.textDisplay:
Frankly, the transport system for the public is ludicrously stupid.

It should be a case of 1 card, 1 payment, any carrier anywhere in the UK and they deal with the BS of claiming from the central fund that your card payments process.

Its one of the reasons I gave up travel on public transport because of all the bullshit rules, restrictions, price hikes and the general crap you have to deal with... Now I have a car, I do not need to worry too much about travel, only problem I have sometimes and its only minor inconvenience when you compare to the shit you have to put up with on rail and bus, is parking.

I pointed out to my local council that it was far cheaper to stump up the running costs of a car and drive in to the city than to take a bus that was often packed, late and over priced... if they want people on public transport, then the government need to adopt a national strategy where all providers of transport have to take or accept a national travel card that you either top up or the payments come immediately out of your bank at each transaction point and travel when you really break it down, is not that costly, we're only sold the notion it is costly because of the dividends share holders get paid their lump of flesh first and the customers and go jolly themselves in the lavs.

I'd say if Beeching hadn't destroyed the rail network, there would be more public transport users than car owners and it would likely of been profitable enough to maintain itself.

Now I have a car, I do not need to worry too much about travel, only problem I have sometimes and its only minor inconvenience when you compare to the shit you have to put up with on rail and bus, is parking.

I pointed out to my local council that it was far cheaper to stump up the running costs of a car and drive in to the city than to take a bus that was often packed, late and over priced... if they want people on public transport, then the government need to adopt a national strategy where all providers of transport have to take or accept a national travel card that you either top up or the payments come immediately out of your bank at each transaction point and travel when you really break it down, is not that costly, we're only sold the notion it is costly because of the dividends share holders get paid their lump of flesh first and the customers and go jolly themselves in the lavs.

I'd say if Beeching hadn't destroyed the rail network, there would be more public transport users than car owners and it would likely of been profitable enough to maintain itself.

snippet.textDisplay: Please note the contactless system excludes blind or visually impaired or severely disabled from access to the tube network according to the London Major and charities. This is illegal and the major could soon criminal charges over this issue. Please note your video seems to think that such software is availble to visually impaired otr blind people. This is a misrepresentation of the position and is discriminatory against those who are currently excluded from travel due to discrimination. This is an ongoing dispute.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm one (possibly two) of the 48 who did this OSI in 2019. I'm surprised the numbers are quite as low as they are, but there are a few reasons why they are low:


Firstly, there are no barriers at either station, so Zone 6 ST holders can (and sometimes will) make the interchange without touching in or out. Additionally, anyone going beyond Upper Warlingham on that line would need a paper ticket anyway.


Secondly, if you're on a train from London/Croydon and heading anywhere between Whyteleafe and Caterham, you're probably better off getting a 407 bus than changing trains. Buses are more frequent and aren't much slower. In fact, sometimes the 407 can actually win a race with the train between Caterham and Whyteleafe. Both are timetabled to take about six minutes and if they're running at the same time it can be quite exciting... (I wonder if Geoff would want to do a video racing Southern trains and the bus between Caterham and Whyteleafe? Best of three wins!)


Finally, if you're travelling in the other direction, from Caterham or Whyteleafe South you'd probably stay on your train and change at East Croydon or Purley. So you'd only do this OSI if you're making a very specific journey like Caterham to Riddlesown or Kenley to Woldingham or something. In most cases there will be bus or bus+train options that make more sense.


Thinking about it, the last time I did this change I had a paper ticket from Caterham to Oxted, so I wouldn't have counted as one of the 48.
snippet.textOriginal:
I'm one (possibly two) of the 48 who did this OSI in 2019. I'm surprised the numbers are quite as low as they are, but there are a few reasons why they are low:


Firstly, there are no barriers at either station, so Zone 6 ST holders can (and sometimes will) make the interchange without touching in or out. Additionally, anyone going beyond Upper Warlingham on that line would need a paper ticket anyway.


Secondly, if you're on a train from London/Croydon and heading anywhere between Whyteleafe and Caterham, you're probably better off getting a 407 bus than changing trains. Buses are more frequent and aren't much slower. In fact, sometimes the 407 can actually win a race with the train between Caterham and Whyteleafe. Both are timetabled to take about six minutes and if they're running at the same time it can be quite exciting... (I wonder if Geoff would want to do a video racing Southern trains and the bus between Caterham and Whyteleafe? Best of three wins!)


Finally, if you're travelling in the other direction, from Caterham or Whyteleafe South you'd probably stay on your train and change at East Croydon or Purley. So you'd only do this OSI if you're making a very specific journey like Caterham to Riddlesown or Kenley to Woldingham or something. In most cases there will be bus or bus+train options that make more sense.


Thinking about it, the last time I did this change I had a paper ticket from Caterham to Oxted, so I wouldn't have counted as one of the 48.

snippet.textDisplay: I've been caught out by the time limits before - touched in at Thames Ditton just after missing the train. By the time I reached Waterloo I had gone over the hour and was charged the maximum. Contacted customer services and they put it right. I now wait until I see the train until I touch in (it's amusing to see how many people get off the train at Watford Junction southbound to touch in on the platform and get back onto the train)
snippet.textOriginal: I've been caught out by the time limits before - touched in at Thames Ditton just after missing the train. snippet.textDisplay: 5:18 “Oh no!”

How many OSI (Out Of Station Interchanges) are there in Greater London. With some closer to each other and some that are within walking distance. Plus will you be riding on the London Overground Class 710/1 AC only Aventra trains which are now operating on the Lea Valley Lines (London Liverpool Street-Chingford, Cheshunt and Enfield Town).

And soon (hopefully) to operate on the Romford-Upminster line very soon. Unless London Overground are to retain 1 Class 315 or Class 317 unit for the Romford-Upminster shuttle. Or maybe London Overground might transfer 1 Class 378 4-Car to operate on the Romford-Upminster line. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Rail_Class_710
snippet.textOriginal:

Plus will you be riding on the London Overground Class 710/1 AC only Aventra trains which are now operating on the Lea Valley Lines (London Liverpool Street-Chingford, Cheshunt and Enfield Town). 

And soon (hopefully) to operate on the Romford-Upminster line very soon. Unless London Overground are to retain 1 Class 315 or Class 317 unit for the Romford-Upminster shuttle. Or maybe London Overground might transfer 1 Class 378 4-Car to operate on the Romford-Upminster line. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Rail_Class_710

snippet.textDisplay: Very close to my heart: when Geoff and Vicky were doing All The stations, I was driving along the A22 and saw them crossing the road while on this very OSI.  I then parked as quickly as I could and walked to Whyteleafe to introduce myself. Made my day!
snippet.textOriginal: Very close to my heart: when Geoff and Vicky were doing All The stations, I was driving along the A22 and saw them crossing the road while on this very OSI.  I then parked as quickly as I could and walked to Whyteleafe to introduce myself. Made my day!

snippet.textDisplay: Interesting about the stats for OSIs, is there potential for a video about some of the most used ones?
snippet.textOriginal: Interesting about the stats for OSIs, is there potential for a video about some of the most used ones?

snippet.textDisplay: Hello Geoff, I think I may be the only person making the Whyteleafe to Upper Walingham OSI. I live near St Pancras and regularly travel to Caterham to see my friends, as you can change between Whyteleafe and Upper Walingham, I stay on the Thameslink train and change there instead of London Bridge. If it is only me I would be very surprised, as I know people to also travel to Caterham from St Pancras too.
snippet.textOriginal: Hello Geoff, I think I may be the only person making the Whyteleafe to Upper Walingham OSI. I live near St Pancras and regularly travel to Caterham to see my friends, as you can change between Whyteleafe and Upper Walingham, I stay on the Thameslink train and change there instead of London Bridge. If it is only me I would be very surprised, as I know people to also travel to Caterham from St Pancras too.

snippet.textDisplay: Geoff, you are suppose to stop as soon as you say Mornington Crescent, that is the end of the game, unless you are playing the George Stephenson rules, but arriving at Mornington Crescent at the beginning of the game is really bad form.

snippet.textDisplay:
I am pleased to understand this. Last trip to the UK I went Epping to Liverpool Street and overground to White Hart Lane. I tapped out at LVS Central Line and back in again on overground and wondered why I was not charged for two journeys. I understand now.

Thank you!
snippet.textOriginal:
I am pleased to understand this. Last trip to the UK I went Epping to Liverpool Street and overground to White Hart Lane. I tapped out at LVS Central Line and back in again on overground and wondered why I was not charged for two journeys. I understand now.

Thank you!

snippet.textDisplay:
Back in BR days you could visit Melksham, Trowbridge, Bath and Chippenham on one day return ticket. I'll leave you to work out the logistics. This was due to there being no "break of journey" restriction, and tickets being issued "by any route". You could do the same thing from Westbury and Frome also.
Ta.
snippet.textOriginal:
Back in BR days you could visit Melksham, Trowbridge, Bath and Chippenham on one day return ticket. I'll leave you to work out the logistics. This was due to there being no "break of journey" restriction, and tickets being issued "by any route". You could do the same thing from Westbury and Frome also.
Ta.
